_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies



The Beaumont Chemical Plant (the plant, stationary source) has a RMP policy to assure adherence to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  The plant complies with the PSM Standard 29CFR1910.119 and thus falls under Program 3 of the RMP rule. The mission of the Beaumont Chemical site is to create a culture of teamwork, personal satisfaction, safety, environmental protection, and continuous improvement that produces products that best meet our customer's needs and ensures the financial success of Goodyer and its associates. 



2. The stationary source and regulated substance handled



The Beaumont Chemical Plant of Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company has a footprint of over 150 developed acres specializing in production of synthetic rubber, synesthetic polyisoprene and monomers. The specialty chemicals and rubber created at the Beaumont Chemical plant are used to create products such as: block polymers, butyl rubber, tires, adhesives, athletic footwear and equipment, fabric coating, baby bottle nipples. medical application, tires, and automotive parts. Each unit has the capability of independent production with facility operating independent from power grid, with many of the critical products to be produced in two units. 

The plant consists of the following covered processes:



1. Natsyn

2. Refrigeration utilities

3. Isoprene

4. General tank farm

5. Budene

6. Utilities water treatment

7. Budene 850

8. 880 Tank Farm



These processes handle, above the threshold, the following highly hazardous chemicals listed by the EPA RMP Rule:



Chlorine

Titanium tetrachloride

Isobutylene

Isoprene

Butadiene-1,3

Propane

Pentane(mixture of isomers)

Hydrogen Fluoride



3. Chemical accident prevention



The facility complies with the PSM Standard.  Hazard assessment (Process Hazard Analyses) have been conducted on the original processes, also conducted on changes that trigger the Manage

ment of Change process. The original PHA are revalidated on a 5-year cycle.  The facility and its equipment are designed according with the recognized good engineering practices and standards such  as ANSI, API, NFPA, ISA, ASME, and others.  PSM/RMP audits are conducted on a 3-year schedule.  The plant has extensive redundant systems to ensure safe operations.  Operators are trained and certified to operate the plant.  They are recertified every 3 years.  The plant is an OSHA VPP STAR site, along with ISO14001 certification.  Management has placed safety and the enforcement as the highest priority for operating the plant.  There are safety and health coordinators assigned to each operating area with sole responsibilities for safety.



4.  Five year accident history



The Goodyear Beaumont Chemical Plant had one incident in 2018 that resulted in a small quantity release, 8 gal of triisobutylalumnimum (TIBA) with mineral oil, due to valve misalignment during truck offloading operations. The plant emergency response team (ERT) responded to fire due to liquid overflow from the top of flame arrestor 5Q-203, with neighboring facility Total Cray Valley sheltering during the response. The investigation resulted in ten (10)  recommendations with actions implemented to prevent reoccurrence by 02/28/2019. 



5. Emergency Response Program



The facility has an Emergency Response Team trained monthly in the theory and practice of responding to emergencies within the plant along with weekly tests of the auditory emergency alert system at the site. With emerging guidelines related to COVID-19, precautions have been taken with more frequent CBT-based drills captured and reviewed weekly by the site Safety Department. The community is informed about ongoing emergencies via the LEPC, Sherriff's department or the Southeast Texas Alert Network (STAN). 



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As part of the Beaumont plant commitment to continuously improving the safety of our proces

ses, some of the initiatives and measures that have been taken or are on-going include:

a. Completed  3rd party PSM / RMP compliance audit in April 2021.

b. Update to site Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) methodology to semi-quantitative Hazard and Operability (HazOp) with integrated high-level Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) for all site PHAs, with full site risk review and ranking to be completed by April 2026.

c. Completed training on PHA methodology to include regulatory compliance requirements with specialization in semi-quantitative methodology of HazOp with high level incorporation of LOPA for site engineering staff

d. Plan to incorporate IPL calculations to validate LOPA safeguards with verification of site critical instrumentation determination criteria

e. Revise PSSR, MOC Risk review checklist, and additional PSM program forms to standardize across company to align with associated project scope requirements and risk levels
